botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Climbing roses are vigorous shrubs with thorny stems and large, solitary or clustered, often fragrant, usually remontant flowers

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thrives in full sun and tolerates shade, suitable for growing as a climber against a wall, trellis or obelisk, can form a shrubby supported hedge. Grow in moist but free-draining or free-draining soil, preferably in full sun. Avoid planting in sites that have previously been used for growing roses. Add mycorrhizal fungi to the roots when planting to help the plant establish quicker.
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by budding or hardwood cuttings
how_to_grow.pruning: Deadhead regularly. Prune after flowering, tie in any new shoots, cut back long shoots by a third, cut back side shoots by two-thirds and removing any dead, dying, damaged and diseased stems
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by brown scale, rose aphids, rose leafhopper, rose leaf-rolling sawfly, large rose sawfly, rose slug sawfly or slugworm, scurfy rose scale, red spider mites, caterpillars, rabbits and deer; leaf-cutting bees may use rose leaves to make nests for their larvae
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by rose black spot, rose rust and rose powdery mildew, canker, crown gall, honey fungus, downy mildew, and virus diseases, and by replant disease and rose dieback; said to be very disease-resistant
